testcase.name: due to @result-type the report shows the output at that port vs. the sequence type condition
due to boolean @test the report shows the output at that port vs. the @test value
without @test and with non-matching document node as expected result the report shows the output at that port vs. the expected result and both sides say "XPath /self::document-node() from:"
without @test and with non-matching document node as expected result Same thing without @select
without @test and with element as expected result the report shows the output at that port vs. the expected result and both sides say "XPath /self::document-node() from:"
with @test that produces a document node the report shows the filtered output at that port vs. the expected result and label above box says "XPath /self::document-node() from:"
with @test that produces the full map of document properties the report shows the map for that port vs. the expected result
with @test that produces a subset of document properties the report shows the map for that port vs. the expected result

with boolean @test related to document properties, not documents, the report shows the documents at that port vs. the @test value (i.e., no special behavior when @test contains $x:document-properties)
with @test that produces an element the report shows the filtered output at that port vs. the expected result and label above box says "XPath /element() from:"
with @test that produces an element Same thing without @select
with @test that produces an atomic value the report shows the atomic value vs. the expected result

testsuite.name: When the output port has multiple documents and x:expect[@port] fails

testcase.name: (Confirm that output at that port is a pair of document nodes)

without @test and with single document node as expected result the report shows the output at that port labeled as "XPath /node() from" (without depicting boundaries between adjacent document nodes) vs. the expected result labeled as "XPath /self::document-node() from"

without @test and with element sequence as expected result the report shows the output at that port labeled as "XPath /node() from" (without depicting boundaries between adjacent document nodes) vs. the expected result labeled as "XPath /node() from"

with @test that produces multiple document nodes and sequence of multiple document nodes as expected result the report shows the output at that port vs. the expected result, both labeled with "XPath /node() from" to indicate multiple nodes (without depicting boundaries between adjacent document nodes)
with @test that produces element nodes the report shows the filtered output at that port vs. the expected result and both sides say "XPath /element() from:"
with @test that produces element nodes Same thing without @select
with @test that produces an atomic value the report shows the atomic value vs. the expected result
